p: Su and colleagues suggested that cranberry juice in general, and proanthocyanidin in particular, inhibits the attachment phase of infecting phages in vitro, possibly via alterating the capsid [ 91]. This suggestion has been confirmed by electron microscopy analysis, which revealed that T4 treated with cranberry juice did not attach to their host [ 95]. Moreover, the feline calicivirus 9 showed structural modification of the capsid upon exposure to cranberry juice [ 91]. Likewise, apple juice, which is rich in procyanidins, increased the resistance of Vero cells against Stx [ 129].
